thread.title: Terror threat to be felt for years: ASIO
thread.title_full: Terror threat to be felt for years: ASIO | Business Spectator

author: AAP
title: Terror threat to be felt for years: ASIO
text:
Never before has terrorism been such a direct and immediate threat to Australia, the nation's spy chief says.
And while Islamic State has been the recent focus of the nation's security agencies, al-Qaeda continues to identify Australia as a "legitimate target", according to the 2014-2015 ASIO Report to Parliament.
The director-general of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, Duncan Lewis, said efforts at countering the threat from terrorism were operating at "a high tempo".
In the report, tabled in the federal parliament on Monday, Mr Lewis also warned that despite "strenuous efforts" there could be "no absolute guarantee that every threat can be identified and mitigated".
"Never before has terrorism been such a direct and immediate threat to our nation and our people," Mr Lewis said in his review of the past year, contained in the report.
In particular, he said, the threat to Australia's interests came from violent extremist idealogies.
"The impact of the conflict in Syria and Iraq will be felt in Australia for many years to come," Mr Lewis said.
The report also warned that while the public threat of some groups had waned, with the high level of attention garnered by ISIL, multiple groups continued to maintain a high degree of intent and capability, "including the capacity to effect or direct a large-scale, complex attack".
The report said al-Qaeda and its affiliates maintained the desire to strike at the West, "and Australia continues to be identified in their propaganda as a legitimate target and location for attack".
In 2014, there were 13,000 terrorist attacks around the world, resulting in 32,727 fatalities - the highest rate of attacks since records were first kept 45 years ago.
At the same time, ASIO had over 400 higher-priority counter-terrorism investigations underway, which amounted to "a two-fold increase" compared to the previous reporting period.
Mr Lewis said the Syrian and Iraq conflict continued to play directly into the terrorism threat to Australia.
He warned it was "unlikely we know the identities of all who are fighting or who have participated in the conflict".
The report also pointed to the ability of ISIL to influence and recruit new members, via "innovative" use of social media.
"Of particular concern is the resonance of ISIL's social media with teenagers aged 14 to 19."
The report said that while the more likely scenario for any attack in Australia was a low-capability attack against a "soft target", perpetrated by a lone actor or small group, "the threat of a complex attack, such as a coordinated mass shooting or a large, sophisticated explosive device, also persists".
